learning_outcomes.description: Understand how social conditions facilitate the production of texts.
Understand how texts reflect the concerns and anxieties of the period in which they were written.
Be able to position key ideas and texts in relation to broader cultural and political conversations.
Appreciate the ability of creative works to interrogate questions central to the human condition.
Understand how texts produced in and about the U.S. have been deployed in the construction of ideas of the West; Western culture; and the individual.
Appreciate the extent to which literary, dramatic, musical, cinematic, and other artistic and historical works of a given period influenced subsequent cultural developments.
Be able to evaluate competing interpretations of a text.
Be able to use evidence to construct arguments.
Work in a group to develop skills and attributes of a collaborative team.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be evaluated on their contribution to class discussion as well as contribution to the module discussion boards on Blackboard. Students are expected to post and reply at least five times during the semester.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
31/03/2026

Presentations will be held during your scheduled seminar time in Week 6 (Tuesday 31 March).
assessments.task_description:
In groups of 3, you will deliver a 15-minute presentation addressing the following prompt: “With close attention to form, as well as content and the context of the selected epic, explain the ways in which one of the following authors – 1.Steinbeck ; 2. Melville; 3. Jacob; 4. or Beecher Stowe;– engages with America’s epic imaginary.”


The presentation will be presented in class, but will be recorded on the day for moderation purposes only.


The University has a collection of resources to assist students with group work. It is recommended you access the following to help prepare you for this assessment item, or to assist with overcoming any problems that may arise:


·      Making groups work (https://www.uq.edu.au/student-services/learning/making-groups-work)


·      Problems associated with group work (https://www.uq.edu.au/student-services/learning/problems-associated-group-work)


·      Stages of group formation (https://www.uq.edu.au/student-services/learning/stages-group-formation)


If you encounter a problem with your team that you cannot resolve through discussion with your fellow group members contact your Course Coordinator. All reasonable attempts to resolve the matter within the group are expected to have been made prior to contacting the Course Coordinator.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
In 2,000 words, students will write a comparative research essay in response to the following essay prompt: “‘Epic often ends up resisting the nation, as much as the form has been enlisted to celebrate the identity and history of many nations over the course of history,’ argues Christopher Phillips. Explain the relationship between epic and nation with close reference to any two epics set on the course.”


Responses must also refer to at least 5 academic sources, to be cited using MLA style and in-text referencing with a complete Reference List. Please note that Reference Lists will not count towards the word limit.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Essay should be submitted via TurnItIn Dropbox on course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students will write a reflective response of 1,200 words addressing the following prompt: “Catherine Bates has argued that the epic ‘is constantly being updated and revived for a modern audience, a flood of new, often celebrated, translations making the texts newly available and accessible to a general readership, while cinematic remakes and the perpetuation of epic motifs in contemporary blockbusters and computer games ensure that the form remains ever present in the popular consciousness’ (Cambridge Companion to the Epic, ix). In its contemporary iterations, what do you think the epic mode continues to offer us as an expression of the United States’ cultural, social, and political dimensions? Discuss with reference to at least one text studied on the course, plus one other American epic of your choosing from outside the course (e.g. a novel; poem; play; film, documentary, or screenplay; essays; musical work; speeches; graphic novel; monument; artwork or multimedia installation; etcetera).


This is not an academic essay: students can respond personally and creatively; but the response should be presented as a coherent piece of writing that demonstrates insight into and understanding of the course concerns at large.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Essay should be submitted via TurnItIn Dropbox on course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to American Epic

Week One:

  • Introduces the idea of the epic as a reflection on the American experience
  • Outlines a list of those ‘epics’ that are part of the American canon
  • Introduces Moby Dick as the seminal ‘epic’ and what it says, and why it says it
  • Questions the role the ‘epic’, such as Moby Dick, in current America

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction to American Epic Week One: Introduces the idea of the epic as a reflection on the American experience Outlines a list of those ‘epics’ that are part of the American canon Introduces Moby Dick as the seminal ‘epic’ and what it says, and why it says it Questions the role the ‘epic’, such as Moby Dick , in current America

learning_activities.topic:
Moby Dick or The Whale (Part 1)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Moby Dick or The Whale (Part 1)

learning_activities.topic:
The Leviathan as a Critique, Then and Now

Week Two:

  • Gives insight into the origins of the book
  • Highlights the themes in, and the intension of the book
  • Shows a host of embedded references, including biblical and others
  • Begins a conversation on what the novel is saying about America
  • Talks on the relevance of this epic in current America

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_title: The Leviathan as a Critique, Then and Now
learning_activities.topic_description: The Leviathan as a Critique, Then and Now Week Two: Gives insight into the origins of the book Highlights the themes in, and the intension of the book Shows a host of embedded references, including biblical and others Begins a conversation on what the novel is saying about America Talks on the relevance of this epic in current America

learning_activities.topic:
Moby Dick or the Whale (Part 2)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Moby Dick or the Whale (Part 2)

learning_activities.topic:
A Nation Built on (In)-Equality

Week Three:

  • Gives an historical overview of slavery in America, including the Civil War
  • Talks on the rise of racists politics including the formation of the KKK
  • Talks on the emancipation movement and the divide between north and south
  • The influence of this on today’s America i.e. political, cultural, social
  • Gives insight into the texts and subsequent others that bought awareness to this condition in America

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: A Nation Built on (In)-Equality Week Three: Gives an historical overview of slavery in America, including the Civil War Talks on the rise of racists politics including the formation of the KKK Talks on the emancipation movement and the divide between north and south The influence of this on today’s America i.e. political, cultural, social Gives insight into the texts and subsequent others that bought awareness to this condition in America

Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_title: Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl
learning_activities.topic_description: Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl

learning_activities.topic:
A Long History of Public Advocacy

Week Four:

  • Gives an overview of the text, including some of the criticism the text received
  • Talks on similar literary ventures across decades
  • Talks on other writers such as Mark Twain who have incorporated similar themes and politics into their writing

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: A Long History of Public Advocacy Week Four: Gives an overview of the text, including some of the criticism the text received Talks on similar literary ventures across decades Talks on other writers such as Mark Twain who have incorporated similar themes and politics into their writing

learning_activities.topic:
Uncle Tom’s Cabin

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Uncle Tom’s Cabin

learning_activities.topic:
The Other Fight: Indigenous Rights

Week Five:

  • Gives historical overview of American Indigenous history
  • Looks at the politics of Indigenous America, including the establishment of reservations
  • Talks on texts that have brought this situation to the attention of nation
  • Considers how this topic / social condition is still shaping current American politics

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: The Other Fight: Indigenous Rights Week Five: Gives historical overview of American Indigenous history Looks at the politics of Indigenous America, including the establishment of reservations Talks on texts that have brought this situation to the attention of nation Considers how this topic / social condition is still shaping current American politics

learning_activities.topic:
Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee

learning_activities.topic:
The Collapse (Or Reinvention) of the American Dream

Week Six:

  • Gives insight into the form of realist writing style and agenda of the Nobel Prize winner
  • Talks on the division between rich and poor in America
  • Speaks on how the Great Depression is formative to the American political and social psyche
  • Talks on more modern incarnations of the theme such as the novel American Psycho

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: The Collapse (Or Reinvention) of the American Dream
learning_activities.topic_description: The Collapse (Or Reinvention) of the American Dream Week Six: Gives insight into the form of realist writing style and agenda of the Nobel Prize winner Talks on the division between rich and poor in America Speaks on how the Great Depression is formative to the American political and social psyche Talks on more modern incarnations of the theme such as the novel American Psycho

learning_activities.topic:
The Grapes of Wrath

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: The Grapes of Wrath

learning_activities.topic:
And So, To War: Masculine America

Week Seven:

  • Explores American tensions with war
  • Talks on the 'masculinist' novelist, including writers such as Hemingway
  • Examines the emergence of protest writing and poetry, including songwriters such as Bob Dylan
  • Talks on more modern American writers who also question U.S. roles in war and battle

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: And So, To War: Masculine America Week Seven: Explores American tensions with war Talks on the 'masculinist' novelist, including writers such as Hemingway Examines the emergence of protest writing and poetry, including songwriters such as Bob Dylan Talks on more modern American writers who also question U.S. roles in war and battle

learning_activities.topic:
The Naked and the Dead

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: The Naked and the Dead

learning_activities.topic:
The Suburban Dream

Week Eight:

  • Talks on the emergence of the American suburban dream
  • Gives insight into the origins of this dream, and cultural ramifications
  • Talks on the emergence of television as a form of promoting this dream
  • Shows how this has ostracised segments of American society
  • Gives insight into the legacy of this American dream

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: The Suburban Dream Week Eight: Talks on the emergence of the American suburban dream Gives insight into the origins of this dream, and cultural ramifications Talks on the emergence of television as a form of promoting this dream Shows how this has ostracised segments of American society Gives insight into the legacy of this American dream

learning_activities.topic:
A Serious Man

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: A Serious Man

learning_activities.topic:
Shifting Perspectives: Migrant Waves of Influence

Week Nine:

  • Revels the history of waves of migration post WW2 and their effect on American culture
  • Shows new genres of narrative: the migrant narrative and the graphic novel
  • Talks on successive waves of migration in the US, from the Dutch colonisers to the present day
  • Talks on the way texts have been influenced by migration, and how assimilation has subsequently shaped US artists

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Shifting Perspectives: Migrant Waves of Influence Week Nine: Revels the history of waves of migration post WW2 and their effect on American culture Shows new genres of narrative: the migrant narrative and the graphic novel Talks on successive waves of migration in the US, from the Dutch colonisers to the present day Talks on the way texts have been influenced by migration, and how assimilation has subsequently shaped US artists

The Joy Luck Club

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: The Joy Luck Club

learning_activities.topic:
Shifting Perspectives: The HIV / AIDs Epidemic

Week Ten:

  • Gives insight into the moving perspective of U.S. identity in relation to the AIDS epidemic
  • Explores America’s relationship with gender and sexuality more generally
  • Looks at the importance of the essay as a form of American literature, and looks at prizes such as the Pulitzer Prize 

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Shifting Perspectives: The HIV / AIDs Epidemic Week Ten: Gives insight into the moving perspective of U.S. identity in relation to the AIDS epidemic Explores America’s relationship with gender and sexuality more generally Looks at the importance of the essay as a form of American literature, and looks at prizes such as the Pulitzer Prize

learning_activities.topic:
Close the Knives

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06, L07, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Close the Knives

learning_activities.topic:
Shifting A Nation, or Reinforcing the Same?

Week Eleven:

  • Looks at America post-9/11
  • Questions today’s politics as a response to this event
  • Looks at the text (in many forms) as a representation of today’s political situation given this new world of social media etc.
  • Reflects on the writing of Safran Foer as a representative of his generation, both literary and social
  • Connects Safran Foer's writing to others in the course

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Shifting A Nation, or Reinforcing the Same?

learning_activities.topic:
Where Are We Now?

Week Twelve:

  • Sums up the semester and gives an overview of the course
  • Reflects on where the U.S. is as a global influencer
  • Questions America’s (and the globe’s) future
  • Reflects on Moby Dick to question the relevance of the themes today

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
